```{python}
#| label: fig-gaussian-pulse
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "Gaussian pulse shaping in time and frequency domain for different bandwidth-time products BT."

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create figure with subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(8, 5))

# Parameters
T = 1.0  # Symbol period
fs = 100 / T  # Sampling frequency (high for smooth curves)
t_span = 4 * T  # Time span to plot
f_span = 6 / T  # Frequency span to plot

# Time and frequency vectors
t = np.linspace(-t_span/2, t_span/2, int(fs * t_span))
f = np.linspace(-f_span, f_span, 1000)

# BT products to plot (bandwidth-time products)
BT_values = [0.3, 0.5]
colors = ['green', 'blue']
linestyles = ['-', '-']

# Plot time domain responses
for i, (BT, color) in enumerate(zip(BT_values, colors)):
    # Gaussian pulse in time domain
    # For BT product: B = BT/T
    B = BT / T  # 3dB bandwidth
    alpha = np.sqrt(np.log(2)/2) * T/BT
    h_t = np.sqrt(np.pi)/alpha * np.exp(- (np.pi * t / alpha)**2)

    ax1.plot(t/T, h_t, color=color, linewidth=2.5, 
             label=f'BT = {BT}', linestyle=linestyles[i])

# Plot frequency domain responses
for i, (BT, color) in enumerate(zip(BT_values, colors)):
    # Gaussian spectrum in frequency domain
    B = BT / T  # 3dB bandwidth
    alpha = np.sqrt(np.log(2)/2) * T/BT
    H_f = np.exp(-alpha**2 * f**2)

    # Convert to dB (20*log10), handle zero values
    H_f_dB = 20 * np.log10(np.maximum(H_f, 1e-10))
    ax2.plot(f * T, H_f_dB, color=color, linewidth=2.5, 
             label=f'BT = {BT}', linestyle=linestyles[i])

# Format time domain plot
ax1.set_xlabel('Time (t/T)')
ax1.set_ylabel('Amplitude h(t)')
ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
ax1.legend(loc='upper right')
ax1.set_xlim(-3, 3)
ax1.set_ylim(0, 2)

# Format frequency domain plot
ax2.set_xlabel('Normalized Frequency (fT)')
ax2.set_ylabel('Magnitude |H(f)| (dB)')
ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
ax2.legend(loc='upper right')
ax2.set_xlim(-3, 3)
ax2.set_ylim(-60, 5)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```
